answers: Horizontal Branch. The process is called the triple-alpha process.

question: The evolution of our Sun on the H-R diagram starting at the main sequence and ending at its last form (last form seen on the H-R diagram) involves 6 main stages, with the first stage being the main sequence and the last stage being the end of fusion. The fifth stage is the asymptotic giant branch phase. What material is the Sun burning during this stage, and where within the Sun is it burning it?
answers: Hydrogen and helium in shells around a carbon-oxygen core

question: The evolution of our Sun on the H-R diagram starting at the main sequence and ending at its last form (last form seen on the H-R diagram) involves 6 main stages, with the first stage being the main sequence and the last stage being the end of fusion. The sixth stage is the end of fusion. What is the fate of the Sun at the end of its fusion (i.e. what stellar remnants are left behind)? One stellar remnant that is left behind can be found on the H-R diagram. Name it, and where in the H-R diagram can that stellar remnant be found?
answers: A white dwarf is left behind. White dwarfs are located in the lower-left portion of the H-R diagram.

question: What are black dwarf stars? Name an example of one.
answers: Theoretical remnants of white dwarfs that have cooled down completely. No known examples exist.

question: Fill in the blanks: Black holes have all their mass concentrated at a single point at their center called the  ___________. Their border is called the ___________, and not even light can escape past this border. If a person got too close to a black hole, they would get horizontally squeezed and stretched out in a process called ___________. The supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way Galaxy is named ___________.
answers: Singularity, Event Horizon, Spaghettification, Sagittarius A*

question: Let’s say a symbiotic binary star system contains a white dwarf. What is the other component of the system? In this system, which component loses mass, and which component gains mass? What happens when the component that gains mass gains too much mass, and what is the name of the limit that is being surpassed when that happens?
answers: A normal star. The normal star loses mass and the white dwarf gains mass. The white dwarf undergoes a Type Ia supernova when it surpasses the Chandrasekhar limit.

question: Let’s say you find a binary system of two white dwarfs in which the white dwarfs are getting closer and closer to each other and will eventually merge. The stars are getting closer to each other because the system is losing energy. How is the system losing energy?
Name and explain the model that describes the outburst behavior of dwarf novae.
answers: Disk Instability Model: Accretion disk builds up until it becomes unstable, causing a burst of accretion onto the white dwarf.

question: Explain what a pulsar is.
answers: A rapidly rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation from its poles.

question: What is a Roche lobe? What happens when a component in a binary system fills its Roche lobe?
answers: The region around a star in a binary system within which orbiting material is gravitationally bound to that star. When a star fills its Roche lobe, it begins to transfer mass to its companion star.

question: Name the astronomical object that is located at the center of a planetary nebula. Why do planetary nebulae glow? What is the origin of the name “planetary nebula?”
answers: A white dwarf. Planetary nebulae glow because the central white dwarf emits ultraviolet radiation that ionizes the surrounding gas. They were originally called "planetary nebulae" because they looked like planets through early telescopes.

question: Explain why a core–collapse supernova occurs.
answers: Occurs when a massive star has burned all its fuel and its core collapses under its own gravity.

question: Explain the core–envelope dichotomy of stars on the red giant branch. The hydrogen–burning shell of stars on the red giant branch is located in between the core and the envelope. What is the name of the process by which hydrogen is fused in the hydrogen–burning shell of red giant branch stars?
answers: The core is inert and made of helium, while the envelope is mostly hydrogen. The process is the proton-proton chain.

question: Explain the dredge–up process that sometimes occurs in asymptotic giant branch stars. Name the new type of star that can result from strong dredge–ups.
answers: Convection brings material from the core to the surface. A carbon star can result from strong dredge-ups.

question: How are stellar black holes formed? How are supermassive black holes are formed (provide two valid theories)?
answers: Stellar black holes are formed from the collapse of massive stars. Supermassive black holes can form by the direct collapse of gas clouds or by the merger of smaller black holes.

question: There is a life cycle for black hole binaries consisting of three stages. Name and describe each stage, in order, and mention gravitational waves in the description of each stage.
answers: Inspiral: Black holes spiral towards each other, emitting gravitational waves. Merger: Black holes collide and merge, emitting a burst of gravitational waves. Ringdown: The newly formed black hole settles into its final state, emitting gravitational waves.

question: What are cataclysmic variables stars? Dwarf novae and classical novae are both types of cataclysmic variable stars; how do the mechanisms by which they occur differ?
answers: Binary star systems in which a white dwarf accretes matter from a companion star. Dwarf novae involve accretion disk instabilities, while classical novae involve thermonuclear runaway on the surface of the white dwarf.

question:
Which of the following studies the infrared spectrum (circle two)?
 a. JWST
 b. Hubble
 c. Spitzer
 d. Chandra
 e. Swift
 f. Fermi
 g. LIGO
Provide two reasons JWST has 18 hexagonal mirrors as opposed to one big mirror?
answers: Easier to manufacture and transport. More resistant to damage.

question: How is the Hubble Space Telescope powered?

Which of the following is NOT a discovery of Spitzer Space Telescope. Circle the answer.
 a. Discovery of Saturn’s largest ring
 b. First telescope to detect light from exoplanet
 c. Mapping of milky way/stellar nurseries
 d. First detection of gravitational waves
options: First telescope to detect light from exoplanet

question: How does the shape of Chandra’s x-ray mirrors differ from typical dish shaped optical mirrors? Why is this the case?
answers: Chandra's mirrors are shaped like barrels because x-rays are high energy and must graze off the mirror rather than reflect.

question: What are the three main instruments that work together in Swift telescope to collect data on Gamma Ray Bursts? Describe each in a sentence.
answers: Burst Alert Telescope (BAT): Detects gamma-ray bursts. X-Ray Telescope (XRT): Obtains x-ray images and spectra of afterglows. Ultraviolet/Optical Telescope (UVOT): Observes afterglows in the ultraviolet and optical wavelengths.

question: Many telescopes, like Fermi, are based in space. Why is this (provide a reason why Fermi specifically needs to be in space)? Why is LIGO not based in space?
answers: Fermi needs to be in space because Earth's atmosphere blocks gamma rays. LIGO is not based in space because it detects gravitational waves, which are not blocked by the atmosphere, and its size makes a space deployment difficult.

question: Describe the difference in spectra between a white dwarf and red giant?
answers: White dwarfs have a bluer, hotter spectrum, while red giants have a redder, cooler spectrum.

question: Rank these in density (lowest to highest): neutron star, red giant, black hole, and white dwarf
answers: Red giant, white dwarf, neutron star, black hole

question: What would spectra of a neutron star look like? Where does its peak generally occur?
answers: Blackbody spectrum. Peaks in the X-ray region.

question: Describe how the luminosity and temperature of a red giant compares to a main sequence star. Why is this the case?
answers: Red giants have a higher luminosity but lower temperature than main sequence stars. This is because they are larger and have a larger surface area.

question: What is a millisecond pulsar? What kind of compact binary system is it?
answers: A very rapidly rotating neutron star. Found in low-mass X-ray binaries.

question: What is the main difference between a low mass and high mass X-ray binary (other than their masses).
answers: Low-mass X-ray binaries contain an old neutron star or black hole, while high-mass X-ray binaries contain a young neutron star or black hole.

question: Why might a compact binary system containing a white dwarf result in a supernova?
answers: The white dwarf can accrete matter from its companion and exceed the Chandrasekhar limit, causing a Type Ia supernova.

question: What causes the two stars in a binary system to sync their rotations?
How does the accretion disk of a black hole binary system contribute to its X-ray emissions?
answers: The material in the accretion disk heats up as it spirals towards the black hole, emitting X-rays.

question: What is the main method of orbital decay of compact binary systems (specifically in neutron star binaries and black hole binaries?
State how the light curves of a Type II–P and Type II–L supernovae differ.
answers: Type II-P supernovae have a plateau in their light curves, while Type II-L supernovae have a linear decline.

question: How are the different elements of the periodic table produced? Name and explain three different mechanisms, being sure to include what types of elements each mechanism produces.
answers: Big Bang nucleosynthesis: Produces hydrogen and helium. Stellar nucleosynthesis: Produces elements up to iron in the cores of stars. Supernova nucleosynthesis: Produces elements heavier than iron during supernova explosions.

question: Rank the following objects from highest surface temperature to lowest surface temperature: red giant branch star, white dwarf, neutron star.
answers: Neutron star, white dwarf, red giant branch star

question: Name a star that is an example of a red giant branch star. Name a star that is an example of a white dwarf.
answers: Aldebaran (red giant branch star), Sirius B (white dwarf)

question: Rank the following objects from highest radius to lowest radius: red giant branch star, white dwarf, neutron star.
answers: Red giant branch star, white dwarf, neutron star

question: Name two ways that asymptotic giant branch stars lose mass (other than transfer of mass to a companion). What is the structural consequence of the fact that asymptotic giant branch stars have great mass loss?
answers: Stellar winds and pulsations. Results in the formation of a planetary nebula.

question: True or false – planetary nebulae typically have a radius of 1 light year.
Fill in the blank – the line at _________ Angstroms is usually the strongest line in the spectra of planetary nebulae.
True or false – white dwarf stars have a higher luminosity than red giant branch stars.
What does the no–hair theorem for black holes state?
answers: Black holes are characterized only by their mass, charge, and angular momentum.

question: Explain why objects with smaller masses have smaller Schwarzschild radii using an equation to justify your answer.
answers: R = 2GM/c^2, Schwarzschild radius is directly proportional to mass.

question: Explain why Type Ia supernovae are helpful for calculating the distance to astronomical objects, using an equation to justify your answer.
answers: They are standard candles, meaning they have a known absolute magnitude. Distance modulus equation: m - M = 5log(d) - 5

question: Why does a neutron star rotate faster than its progenitor (assume mass stays constant)? Use an equation to justify your answer.
answers: Conservation of angular momentum. L = Iω, where I is the moment of inertia and ω is the angular velocity. When a star collapses into a neutron star, its radius decreases, decreasing its moment of inertia, which causes its angular velocity to increase.

question: Imagine the radius of two astronomical bodies was somehow tripled, the mass of body 1 was doubled and the mass of body 2 was halved. What would happen to the Force? Justify with an equation.
answers: F = G(m1m2)/r^2. Force would decrease by a factor of 18.

question: If the semi-major axis increases by a factor of 2, how much will the period increase by? Support this with an equation.
answers: Kepler's Third Law: P^2 ∝ a^3. Period will increase by a factor of 2.83.

question: Given an astronomical body with a constant radius, what would happen to temperature when luminosity decreases by a factor of 81?
answers: L = 4πR^2σT^4. The temperature will decrease by a factor of 3.

question: What is the relationship between luminosity and period for cepheids?
answers: The longer the period, the higher the luminosity.

question: What is the deciding factor(s) of the Swartzchild radius? In other words, what factor(s) varies in each situation and determines what the Swartzchild radius is. What is the relationship between this factor and the Swartzchild radius?
answers: Mass. Directly proportional, as mass increases, so does the Swartzchild radius.

question: What is the change in absolute magnitude when distance increases?
answers: Absolute magnitude does not change with distance; it is the apparent magnitude that changes.

question: What happens to a planet's orbital speed when its period increases. Justify this with any equations/laws necessary.
answers: Orbital speed decreases. According to Kepler's Third Law: P^2 ∝ a^3. So if period increases the orbital radius increases so the velocity has to decrease.

question: What stars is the Hulse-Taylor system composed of? Why is it special?
answers: A pulsar and a neutron star. It provided the first evidence for gravitational waves.

question: What’s the apparent magnitude of the brightest star in the night sky? What are the spectral types of the two stars in that system?

answers: 2 times more massive and 25 times more luminous

Describe TWO scientifically plausible reasons why a globular cluster is an unlikely candidate for contacting possible sentient species.
answers: Globular clusters are very old, so most life-supporting stars (high mass) have already died out, or those that are still alive (low mass) are not expected to harbor the complex elements needed for life.
Stars in globular clusters are metal-poor. This means that there aren't enough heavy elements to form rocky planets
Stars in globular clusters are tightly packed and undergo frequent gravitational interactions, making long-term stable planetary orbits unlikely.

question:
RS Puppis exhibits a fascinating phenomenon known as light echos! These light echos occur when an object’s light becomes scattered by dust and can give off the effect of superluminal (faster than light) expansion. If the scattering causes photons to travel towards Earth, there is enough dust to create a significant scattering effect, and the photons themselves have enough energy, we can observe light echos. It is always exciting to find light echoes as they are rare!
The light echos can be used to geometrically determine the distance to a Cepheid. The question may arise as to why this distance is needed if Cepheids are standard candles whose distance can be determined using the Period-Luminosity relation. Why is this distance useful?
answers: It can calibrate the period luminosity relationship.

Why do astronomers believe that the system is between a white dwarf and black hole rather than a white dwarf and neutron star (specifically, a transitional millisecond pulsar)?
answers: The orbital period is too short (28 minutes). In a transitional millisecond pulsar, the white dwarf will have filled up the Roche lobe and mass transfer is taking place, slowing the orbit.

question: X9 is a low mass X-ray binary. What is the difference between a high-mass X-ray binary (HMXB) and a low-mass X-ray binary (LMXB), in terms of what two objects constitute the binary, and how the binary is formed?
answers:
HMXB: massive star (OB star) + neutron star or black hole. The massive star loses mass via stellar wind which is captured by the neutron star or black hole.
LMXB: low mass star + neutron star or black hole. The low mass star fills up the Roche lobe and loses mass to the neutron star or black hole.

A series of light curves are shown in image C3A around the phase of inferior conjunction at different epochs, three showing strong flaring, and the two during weak flaring. The period of eclipsing is found to be 0.3 days. A model light curve for the binary with a white dwarf and a secondary star is shown as an overlay to represent the ideal eclipsing binary behavior. Here the mass ratio is assumed as 0.5, and the inclination angle indicates an almost edge-on orbit (i = 81°). The variation in magnitude of the model curve is quite significant. What is the equivalent ratio of radius for the eclipsing WD versus that of the secondary star, based on this variation? Assuming WD has much lower surface brightness.

A rare CV binary system was found with strong eclipsing of the secondary star accompanied by the flaring activities. A series of light curves are shown in image C3A around the phase of inferior conjunction at different epochs, three showing strong flaring, and the two during weak flaring. The period of eclipsing is found to be 0.3 days. A model light curve for the binary with a white dwarf and a secondary star is shown as an overlay to represent the ideal eclipsing binary behavior. Here the mass ratio is assumed as 0.5, and the inclination angle indicates an almost edge-on orbit (i = 81°). Does your answer match the characteristics of a WD size and typical CV companion star? Explain briefly the eclipsing magnitude. (Note the strong contrast in eclipsing magnitude of the strong vs. weak flaring case.)
answers:
WD size should be much smaller than the companion star which are typically red giants or at least much larger than earth radius. Mostly the accreting material around the WD is causing the large magnitude change.
The gas transferred from the secondary star is filling the orbits around the WD, creating a shrouded region (Roche lobe) that is much bigger than the WD itself. The flare region, with denser gas (stronger influxes of gas ionized by the strong magnetic field) is potentially the main area blocking the secondary star.

question: A rare CV binary system was found with strong eclipsing of the secondary star accompanied by the flaring activities. A series of light curves are shown in image C3A around the phase of inferior conjunction at different epochs, three showing strong flaring, and the two during weak flaring. The period of eclipsing is found to be 0.3 days. A model light curve for the binary with a white dwarf and a secondary star is shown as an overlay to represent the ideal eclipsing binary behavior. A series of light curves are shown in image C3A around the phase of inferior conjunction at different epochs, three showing strong flaring, and the two during weak flaring. The period of eclipsing is found to be 0.3 days. A model light curve for the binary with a white dwarf and a secondary star is shown as an overlay to represent the ideal eclipsing binary behavior. Based on the inclination (i = 81°) and period (0.3 days), what is the distance in km between the secondary star and the center of mass for the binary system? Assume circular motion.

A series of light curves are shown in image C3A around the phase of inferior conjunction at different epochs, three showing strong flaring, and the two during weak flaring. The period of eclipsing is found to be 0.3 days. A model light curve for the binary with a white dwarf and a secondary star is shown as an overlay to represent the ideal eclipsing binary behavior. For variable stars and pulsars, O-C diagrams (observed-minus-calculated) are extremely powerful to detect subtle changes in the time series and its periods. Images C4A through C4C shows the O-C diagram for the three following objects. A is the amplitude of the light curve in the V band and p is the period in days. The general fit for the O-C curve is the function f (E) = a + bE + cE2 where E is the epoch (number of cycles). Object A has a Teff ∼ 7000 K. What is the period change in (second/year)? Based on this, describe the most likely evolution path object A is going through in the H-R diagram and the reason.
answers: 4.43 sec/yr. Increasing period indicates larger radius, so it is going through the instability strip from left to right (high Teff suggests first time. The plot is for the Polaris)

question: For variable stars and pulsars, O-C diagrams (observed-minus-calculated) are extremely powerful to detect subtle changes in the time series and its periods. Images C4A through C4C shows the O-C diagram for the three following objects. A is the amplitude of the light curve in the V band and p is the period in days. The general fit for the O-C curve is the function f (E) = a + bE + cE2 where E is the epoch (number of cycles). For object B, what is the change of the period and its magnitude in (second/year)? Describe the type of the object. What is the most likely evolution path object B is going through on the H-R diagram?
answers: -3.10 sec/yr (period getting shorter). It is going through the instability strip from right to left — likely the second or fourth crossing of the instability strip.

question: For variable stars and pulsars, O-C diagrams (observed-minus-calculated) are extremely powerful to detect subtle changes in the time series and its periods. Images C4A through C4C shows the O-C diagram for the three following objects. A is the amplitude of the light curve in the V band and p is the period in days. The general fit for the O-C curve is the function f (E) = a + bE + cE2 where E is the epoch (number of cycles). Rather than removing the sinusoidal wave, it can also be assumed that the variation from one cycle to the next is random with magnitude e, and that the variable u(x) represents the variation in O-C value accumulated over x period, compared to the ephemeris. The average of cycle-to-cycle variation  is proportional to the number of cycles x if the period fluctuation e is significant. Image C4D shows such post-processing of variability in the O-C diagram. What is the period fluctuation e in (days) based on Image C4D? How does it compare with the long-term period changes based on O-C parabola fit?
answers: fluctuation in period is 0.7 days. This is much larger than the period change of 81 sec/year for the overall reduction of periods.

In the Wegener–Bergeron–Findeisen process, the properties of these particles affect the ratio of droplets to ice crystals required for the process to proceed. When these particles have radii less than 0.2 micrometers, they are referred to as the Aitken variety. Examples include soot, sulfate, kaolinite, and salt. The existence of these particles drastically reduces the relative humidity required for cloud formation to begin. For ten points, name these small particles on which water vapor condenses.

This molecule can be used to treat KRAS oncogenic mutations by targeting deregulated cellular energetics through GLUT1 transporters. This molecule, produced by the Reichstein process cannot be synthesized in humans because our form of L-gulonolactone oxidase is highly mutated. In the 1700s, James Lind began treating pirates with scurvy with citrus fruit, which are rich with this molecule. For 10 points, name the vitamin also known as ascorbic acid, commonly found in citrus fruits, broccoli, strawberries, and other foods.

In algebra, this word refers to a ring element that has an inverse. A matrix with property given by this word is the identity element of the general linear group. Dividing by the magnitude of a vector produces a new vector with property characterized by this word. The astronomical variety of this word is defined as the distance between the Earth and the Sun. Trigonometric functions are often defined with respect to a circle of radius 1, which is usually described as a “circle” preceded by this word. For ten points, scientists usually collect measurements using the International System of what word, abbreviated SI?

In the year 2000, Robert Solovay was presenting a talk on one of his novel algorithms which had to do with circuits with only one of these when he was interrupted by a fire alarm. DiVencenzo’s criteria says that for a specific type of computer to be constructed, it must have the ability to initialize the state of these to a simple fiducial state. One of these can be represented with a Bloch sphere, where each point on its surface maps to a state of this unit of information. In 2001, IBM used Shor’s algorithm to factor the number 15 with only 7 of these. For ten points, name the quantum counterpart to a classical bit.

This plant region, which is nonexistent in wheat embryos, grows asymmetrically during apical hook formation. The fungus Rhizoctonia solani affects this part of the plant, where resistance correlates with the thickness of this plant part. The plumule of a plant consists of this region, young leaves, and the shoot apical meristem. For 10 points, identify the embryonic shoot above cotyledons in plants.

This type of rock is the most common igneous rock in Earth’s crust, produced by submarine volcanism at mid-ocean ridges and make up much of the ocean crust. This type of basaltic magma is initially generated as partial melts of peridotite (olivine and pyroxene) produced by decompression melting of the Earth’s mantle. This type of basalt constituting the oceanic crust is termed MORB: mid-ocean-ridge basalt. It describes the evolution of a mafic magma into a more evolved, silica rich end member. Rock types of this series include this type of basalt, ferro-basalt, this type of basaltic andesite, this type of andesite, dacite and rhyolite. For ten points, name the series which is one of two main series in subalkaline igneous rocks.

This mineral is associated with volcanic structures that are formed by the sudden expansion of volatiles. Lamproites and another igneous rock that is found exclusively in Archaean cratons sometimes contain this mineral. Owing to the conditions this mineral forms under, it is often used in experiments that simulate the high pressures of Earth’s interior. Experiments indicate that abundant amounts of this mineral condense from methane on Uranus and Neptune. For ten points, name this mineral that has a hardness of 10 on the Mohs scale.

This meteorite’s fossil variety has its original material largely replaced by terrestrial secondary mineralization but retains grains of relict spinel. The event associated with this meteorite may form glassy, gravel sized objects completely lacking microlites or phenocrysts. The modern classification scheme groups this type of meteorite based on structure, chemical and isotopic composition. When this meteorite is large enough to create an impact crater, geologists refer to it as referred to as a bolide. For ten points, name this piece of debris from space that survives its passage through the atmosphere to reach the surface of a planet or moon.

This series of genes, typically in bacteria, will be transcribed together to make enzymes that will all assist to complete the same task. In 1961, a paper was published by Jacob and Monod detailing their discovery of enzyme induction in E. coli as the result of this certain unit of genes. They discovered a negatively regulated system prominent in enteric bacteria. This group of genes turns on and off in response to its Catabolite activator protein and a certain repressor. For ten points, name the operon that controls the expression of genes that regulate the breakdown of lactose.

This data structure, Queue, is used in most implementations of the breadth-first search graph algorithm, and can be constructed as the equivalence classes of an ordered pair of integers. This data structure is used in the Huffman compression algorithm to construct lowest-frequency trees, with numbers can be constructed as the equivalence classes of an ordered pair of integers. This letter represents a set of numbers that is famously dense over the set of reals, and can be expressed as the quotient of two relatively prime integers. For ten points, name the 17th letter of the alphabet representing the set of rationals, which when pronounced, sounds like a first-in-first-out data structure.

This event was partly caused by the breakup of the Weddellian Isthmus. Prior to this event, Arecaceae, Fagus, and Pinophyta were common taxa on a continent which shares its name with this event. This event primarily began in the southern hemisphere, while its defining characteristic would not spread to the northern hemisphere for nearly 30 million years, after the Isthmus of Panama was closed. Beginning around 22 million years after the PETM, atmospheric carbon dioxide levels were around 750 ppm. This event’s namesake continent would be covered by its namesake characteristic by around 28 million years ago. The Great American Interchange occurred 9.5 million years ago during this event. This event is still ongoing, although it is currently an interstadial period. For ten points, name the current period of worldwide cooler temperatures which saw the rise of many hominid species, mastodons, and smilodons.

This laboratory technique, invented in 1983 by Kary Mullis, has been modified to detect CpG islands in genomic DNA. It is also an important technique that can be used to detect adaptive mutations in cancer patients by detecting ctDNA levels , and often uses Taq polymerase from the bacterium Thermus aquaticus. Mullis used Sanger sequencing as the basis for this technique, adding a second primer and repeatedly using DNA polymerase. For 10 points, name the laboratory technique that allows scientists to amplify a very small sample of DNA by using thermal cycling, primers, and DNA polymerase.

Abstract machines can be described as being either stack machines or machines of this kind. Compilers often include an allocator for these. In one type of exploit, control over the program is gained by writing an arbitrary value into one of these. SP is an example of this, as is the 64-bit RAX. These are often used by processors as targets for arithmetic operations. For ten points, name this word, whose “cash” version goes “ka-ching!” when a cashier opens its box.

This data structure, Heap, is a type of data structure can perform this kind of overflow, and where priority queues are primarily represented with this data structure of the same name, which itself is represented with a tree. In the C programming language, the malloc (“ma-LOCK”) keyword can be used to allocate memory to this section of memory. For ten points, name this area of dynamically allocated memory present in running programs.

The long type of these events may be caused by the shedding of the hydrogen envelope of Wolf-Rayet stars. The short type of these events is theorized to be caused by the merging of binary neutron stars. (*) These events are the most energetic and bright in the universe, and can last between ten milliseconds and several hours. For ten points, name the energetic explosions from distant galaxies that are named after the most energetic portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.

The oldest of this type of fossil can date back to around 1800 million years ago, attributed to amoebae. Some of the most famous examples of this type of fossil are found in Dinosaur Valley State Park at the Paluxy (“pa-lux-ee”) River site. Unable to be fully attributed to specific species (*), this fossil type can inform paleontologists of an organism’s movements, diet, and behavior, as well as the energy level of the depositional environment. For ten points, name this fossil type, which commonly includes footprints, tracks, burrows, and fossilized feces.

This type of galaxy constitutes approximately 10 to 15 percent of all galaxies in the Virgo Supercluster. This type of galaxy is composed of more population two stars than population one stars. (*) It is believed that this type of galaxy will result from the collision of the Milky Way and Andromeda Galaxies in four to five billion years. For ten points, name this smooth and large type of galaxy that is denoted by an E in the Hubble Sequence.

The supraglacial variety of this feature can form when debris accumulates due to surfaceward ice flow near the zone of ablation. The sediment comprising these structures is often unstratified and unsorted, with particle sizes ranging from silt to boulders. (*) This feature has many types, such as recessional, lateral, terminal and medial. For ten points, name this term describing any accumulation of glacial till.

At an amphidromic point, this value is zero. This value is greatest when the Sun, Moon, and Earth are in syzygy. (*) This value is the greatest at the Bay of Fundy, where the funnel shape causes resonance. For ten points, name the height difference between the high and low levels of the periodic change in sea level caused by the gravitational forces of the Moon, the Sun, and the Earth’s rotation.

This weather cycle relates to Walker circulation, which is caused by a pressure gradient between high pressure (*) over the Pacific Ocean and low pressure over the Indian Ocean. With three phases, this cycle dramatically affects local fishing industries in South America, and typically a cycle lasts from 7 to 11 years. One of these phases is characterized by warmer than average ocean surface temperatures near the Pacific Coast of South America. For ten points, name this periodic weather phenomena whose name is Spanish for “the boy.”

This layer of the earth contains a relatively large concentration of sodium that is regularly replenished by incoming meteors. This layer absorbs most of the incoming gamma and X-ray radiation (*) aimed at the Earth. Cosmological events, most notably auroras, occur within this layer. For ten points, name the layer of the earth that has the highest recorded temperatures.

The minerals coesite and stishovite form when silica is subjected to the shock type of this process. The Barrovian type of this process occurs at continental-continental convergent boundaries. The contact type of this process occurs at the aureoles of plutons. (*) This process occurs when a rock is subjected to high pressures, high temperatures, or chemically active fluids. For ten points, name the process that alters the texture and mineral composition of pre-existing rocks without melting.

Tvashtar Paterae on Jupiter’s moon Io is likely the largest example of this type of structure in the solar system. Only seven collapses that form these structures have occurred between 1911 and 2016, (*) with the most recent occurring at the summit of Kilauea. There are three main types of this structure: Crater Lake, Hawaiian, and Yellowstone. For ten points, name the large depression that forms at the summit of a volcano following the emptying of the magma chamber.

For a wide mass range, this type of star’s luminosity is proportional to its mass to the power of 3.5. The Hayashi track is a luminosity-temperature relationship obeyed by stars transitioning onto this portion of the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram. (*) For more massive stars of this type, nuclear fusion is primarily driven by the CNO cycle. For ten points, name the portion of the H-R diagram that extends from the upper left to the lower right.
Jupiter is more massive than all the other planets in our solar system put together.
Sunlight requires nearly 25 seconds to reach Earth.
Of the four inner planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars), Mars has the coolest surface temperature.
The equator of the sun rotates faster than the poles of the sun.
The Oort cloud is outside of the Sun’s gravitational pull and thus the boundary of the solar system.
New Horizons was the first space probe to achieve escape velocity to leave the solar system.
Apart from Earth, only the outer planets have enough mass to gravitation-ally attract and hold a moon.
Shepherd moons orbit on the edge of a planet’s rings, so its gravity keeps the rings in a tight band rather than their natural tendency to spread farther apart.
Tycho Brahe’s work was a predecessor to Kepler’s Laws of Planetary Motion.
The Opportunity rover has observed photometric transits of Phobos.

Which of the following are factors for planet habitability? Select all that apply.

question: Which of the following are hypotheses for why Venus’s magnetic field is much weaker than Earth’s?
options: Venus has a conductive liquid rather than a non-conductive/insulating liquid in its core, so it cannot produce a magnetic field
Venus’s core is completely solid, so there is no liquid that could rotate to produce a magnetic field
Venus’s magnetic field has been worn down because it is closer to the Sun’s radiation and solar winds
Venus actually has a stronger magnetic field than Earth

options: Enceladus hides liquid salty water beneath its crust
Ganymede has a liquid saltwater layer
Jupiter has larger thunderstorms than Earth

question: Which of the following are true about Iapetus?
options: It is tidally locked with Saturn
It has a ridge that closely follows the equator, perhaps as icy material that welled up to the surface and then solidified

question: The first one of this object was discovered by Abraham Ihle in 1665, and is among the oldest objects in the universe. In 1939, Pieter Oosterhoff noticed there were two populations of this object, thus forming the Oosterhoff groups. Compared to the sun, this object contains a much lower proportion of metals to Hydrogen and Helium. A famous example of one of these objects is 47 Tucanae, which is the second brightest one of these objects in the night sky. A Hertzsprung-Russell diagram of this object will display a main-sequence turnoff point, which can be used to estimate the age of this object. For 10 points, name this spherical collection of old Population II stars, which the Milky Way contains approximately 150 of.

This quantity of a material can be related to the single free parameter and incident angle by the Heyney-Greenstein phase function. This quantity’s V-band and Bond variants can refer to different things in astronomy, while a high radar value of this quantity for an asteroid can be indicative of high metallic content. This quantity’s increase can lead to a positive feedback loop with ice, and Saturn’s moon Enceladus has the highest value of this quantity of any body in the Solar System due to its white, icy surface. For 10 points, name this quantity, the percentage of incident radiation which is reflected, for which a perfect blackbody has a value of 1.

The name of these stars may be followed by a “+OB” or “+abs” suffix if their spectra contain companion absorption lines. “Slash stars” are examples of these stars with similar characteristics to Class O stars and they also name a class of luminous starburst galaxies. Planetary nebulae with these stars at their center are often associated with large astrospheres. The prototypical example of these stars is found within the Gamma Velorum system. They are characterized by a set of strikingly broad helium, carbon, nitrogen and oxygen emission lines and extremely strong stellar winds. For 10 points, name these doubly-eponymous stars that make up Class W in the extended Harvard classification system.
H1821+643 is classified as a quasar, which is a type of active galactic nucleus. Which of the following is NOT true of AGNs?
options: Quasars are powered by matter falling into their central supermassive black holes
Quasars are usually radio-quiet, while Seyfert galaxies are usually radio-loud
Quasars are distinct from Seyfert galaxies in that the central SMBH usually outshines the entire galaxy
Quasars are more common in the early universe than today

SN UDS10Wil is among the most distant supernovae detected to date. When SN UDS10Wil occurred, the universe was approximately what fraction of its size today? (More precisely, distances back then were what fraction of the corresponding distance today?)

Are these distances the same? Do you expect them to be the same?

What is the eccentricity of the comet with minimum perihelion of 0.2 AU?

Assuming a perihelion of 0.2 AU, what is comet Charlotte’s orbital velocity at perihelion? Use the Vis-Viva equation, which is 𝑣^2 = 𝐺𝑀( 2/𝑟 − 1/𝑎 ) where r is the orbital distance, a is the semi-major axis, and v is the orbital velocity at that distance.

What is the value of the constant G’ in SI units, given that Robette changed the universal law of gravity from an inverse-squared law to an inverse-cubed law (i.e. gravity is now governed by F = G’Mm/r3 instead of F = GMm/r2, where G’ is a new constant of gravity), and Earth’s orbit still stayed the same?

True or False: The force of gravity on Mercury from the sun would become greater than it was before, given that Robette changed the universal law of gravity from an inverse-squared law to an inverse-cubed law (i.e. gravity is now governed by F = G’Mm/r3 instead of F = GMm/r2, where G’ is a new constant of gravity), and Earth’s orbit still stayed the same?

True or False: The force of gravity on Jupiter from the sun would be greater than it was before, given that Robette changed the universal law of gravity from an inverse-squared law to an inverse-cubed law (i.e. gravity is now governed by F = G’Mm/r3 instead of F = GMm/r2, where G’ is a new constant of gravity), and Earth’s orbit still stayed the same?

options: It would fall towards the sun into a closer orbit
It would stay in the same orbit
It would veer into an orbit farther from the sun

question: What would happen to Jupiter after gravity was suddenly changed from an inverse-squared law to an inverse-cubed law?
options: It would fall towards the sun into a closer orbit
It would stay in the same orbit

question: True or False: Kepler’s 1st law would still be valid after gravity was suddenly changed from an inverse-squared law to an inverse-cubed law?

Estimate the temperature of Gojo’s Eye in Kelvins, modeling a blue-white A0-type star the size of the iris (R ~ 6 mm).
